items.title: validate_statistics does not support struct_stats
items.body:
When using the validate_statistics api on some actual data, we noticed that `struct_stats` are not supported. 

https://github.com/tensorflow/data-validation/blob/v0.22.2/tensorflow_data_validation/api/validation_api.py#L499-L506

My understanding is that `struct_stats` include data represented as tensors which are a critical for data type for a number of use cases.

items.title: Error while running Tutorial of Tensorflow Data Validation
items.body:
While running the command, `!pip install -q tensorflow_data_validation[visualization]` in Google Colab using **Run in Google Colab** option, mentioned in the [TF DV Tutorial](https://www.tensorflow.org/tfx/tutorials/data_validation/tfdv_basic), it is resulting in the Error shown below:

```
ERROR: pydrive 1.3.1 has requirement oauth2client>=4.0.0, but you'll have oauth2client 3.0.0 which is incompatible.
ERROR: jupyter-console 5.2.0 has requirement prompt-toolkit<2.0.0,>=1.0.0, but you'll have prompt-toolkit 3.0.5 which is incompatible.
ERROR: google-colab 1.0.0 has requirement ipython~=5.5.0, but you'll have ipython 7.15.0 which is incompatible.
ERROR: google-colab 1.0.0 has requirement pandas~=1.0.0; python_version >= "3.0", but you'll have pandas 0.25.3 which is incompatible.
ERROR: chainer 6.5.0 has requirement typing-extensions<=3.6.6, but you'll have typing-extensions 3.7.4.2 which is incompatible.
```
Also, when running the Command, `train_stats = tfdv.generate_statistics_from_csv(data_location=TRAIN_DATA)`, it is resulting in the Error, `AttributeError: module 'pyarrow.types' has no attribute 'is_large_list' [while running 'GenerateStatistics/RunStatsGenerators/GenerateSlicedStatisticsImpl/TopKUniquesStatsGenerator/ToTopKTuples']`.

It's always good to have Documentation free of Errors. Hope this will be fixed. Thank you.

items.title: Pinned Pandas <1 versioning
items.body:
Hi there, I was wondering if it would be possible to upgrade the setup.py pinned dependencies to accept pandas 1.0.X. It includes a few performance upgrades and this version pin is blocking us on upgrading our local version of Pandas to tap into those performance upgrades.

Is there any specific reason why Pandas is pinned to <1?

items.title: validate_statistics() does not use DatasetConstraints when identifying anomalies
items.body:
Python: 3.7.5
TFDV: 0.15.0

I want to identify when my dataset contains fewer rows than expected. I am attempting to do so by configuring the `DatasetConstraint` message of the schema protobuf. However, this does not seem to work.

Code to reproduce the issue:

```python
df = pd.DataFrame({"age": [15, 20, 25]})
stats = tfdv.generate_statistics_from_dataframe(df)
schema = tfdv.infer_schema(stats)
schema.dataset_constraints.min_examples_count = 4
tfdv.display_anomalies(tfdv.validate_statistics(stats, schema))
```

Instead of flagging the dataset as anomalous, this indicates that there are `No anomalies found`. Am I missing something?

items.title: Std dev computed using tfdv.generate_statistics_from_dataframe is incorrect
items.body:
Using `tfdv.generate_statistics_from_dataframe` to generate statistics produces std dev values that are incorrect.

## Expected Behavior
<!--- Tell us what should happen -->
It should compute the correct std dev over the dataset.

## Current Behavior
<!--- Tell us what happens instead of the expected behavior -->

The existing formula for incrementally computing the standard deviation is:
 ```sqrt(sum_of_squares/num_values - mean ** 2)``` 
([code](https://github.com/tensorflow/data-validation/blob/master/tensorflow_data_validation/statistics/generators/basic_stats_generator.py#L457))

This produces values that are incorrect.

## Possible Solution
<!--- Not obligatory, but suggest a fix/reason for the bug, -->
[This method of computing variance incrementally](https://stats.stackexchange.com/a/384951) works well; I've tested it on multiple small-sized datasets, and it produces variances approximately equal to variances computed over the full dataset using pandas. 

## Steps to Reproduce
<!--- Provide a link to a live example, or an unambiguous set of steps to -->
<!--- reproduce this bug. Include code to reproduce, if relevant -->

```
>> # using a toy dataset:
>> df = pd.DataFrame(
    {
        "ints": [4, 3, 2, 6, 3, 2, 6, 7],
        "floats": [2.1, 5.2, 4.3, 0.6, 0.1, 1.6, 2.4, 2],
    }
)

>> # computing std dev with pandas
>> df.std()

ints      1.959410
floats    1.722488
dtype: float64

>> # computing std dev with tfdv
>> stats = tfdv.generate_statistics_from_dataframe(df)
>> for feature in stats.datasets[0].features:
        print(f"name: {feature.path.step[0]}, std_dev: {feature.num_stats.std_dev}")

name: ints, std_dev: 1.8328597873268975
name: floats, std_dev: 1.6112398176559561
```

## Context (Environment)
<!--- How has this issue affected you? What are you trying to accomplish? -->
<!--- Providing context helps us come up with a solution that is most useful in the real world -->
```
tensorflow-data-validation==0.21.2
```
(not the latest, but std dev computation has not changed since this version)

items.title: At AI Platform Pipeline tutorial, stats_impl.py raises AttributeError on Dataflow.
items.body:
At step 8 of [tfx/template.ipynb](https://github.com/tensorflow/tfx/blob/master/docs/tutorials/tfx/template.ipynb), `AttributeError` raises at line 652 of stats_impl.py.

## How to reproduce

SInce the TFX template command has some bugs at the version 0.21.2, we have to make some fix to reproduce the error. Both are at Step 7 of [tfx/template.ipynb](https://github.com/tensorflow/tfx/blob/master/docs/tutorials/tfx/template.ipynb).

### `BEAM_PIPELINE_ARGS`

Since default storage size is 25 GB, runners run out the persistent disk space. We have to increase it to 50 GB. We can change it by changing `BEAM_PIPELINE_ARGS` in `configs.py` as following;

```python
BEAM_PIPELINE_ARGS = [
   '--project=' + GCP_PROJECT_ID,
   '--runner=DataflowRunner',
   '--experiments=shuffle_mode=auto',
   '--temp_location=' + os.path.join('gs://', GCS_BUCKET_NAME, 'tmp'),
   '--region=' + GCP_REGION,
   '--disk_size_gb=50',
   ]
```

See also https://github.com/tensorflow/tfx/pull/1449

### `BIG_QUERY_QUERY`

`BigQueryExampleGen` should returns nullable string at the `pickup_census_tract` row, however, default query returns INT values and it causes an error. In the `configs.py`, we have to fix the query to BigQuery as following;

```python
BIG_QUERY_QUERY = """
        SELECT
          pickup_community_area,
          fare,
          EXTRACT(MONTH FROM trip_start_timestamp) AS trip_start_month,
          EXTRACT(HOUR FROM trip_start_timestamp) AS trip_start_hour,
          EXTRACT(DAYOFWEEK FROM trip_start_timestamp) AS trip_start_day,
          UNIX_SECONDS(trip_start_timestamp) AS trip_start_timestamp,
          pickup_latitude,
          pickup_longitude,
          dropoff_latitude,
          dropoff_longitude,
          trip_miles,
          SAFE_CAST(pickup_census_tract AS STRING) AS pickup_census_tract,
          dropoff_census_tract,
          payment_type,
          company,
          trip_seconds,
          dropoff_community_area,
          tips
        FROM `bigquery-public-data.chicago_taxi_trips.taxi_trips`
        WHERE (ABS(FARM_FINGERPRINT(unique_key)) / 0x7FFFFFFFFFFFFFFF)
          < {query_sample_rate}""".format(
   query_sample_rate=_query_sample_rate)
```

See also https://github.com/tensorflow/tfx/pull/1518

### `_query_sample_rate`

To use Dataflow, we have to increase `_query_sample_rate` since kfp will not call Dataflow with the default value. I changed the value 100 times bigger.

```python
# _query_sample_rate = 0.0001  # Generate a 0.01% random sample.
_query_sample_rate = 0.01  # Generate a 1% random sample.
```

### Update pipeline

After making these changes, we can reproduce the error with the following command (same as command cell in step 8 of [tfx/template.ipynb](https://github.com/tensorflow/tfx/blob/master/docs/tutorials/tfx/template.ipynb));

```bash
!tfx pipeline update \
--pipeline_path=kubeflow_dag_runner.py \
--endpoint={ENDPOINT}
!tfx run create --pipeline_name {PIPELINE_NAME} --endpoint={ENDPOINT}
```

## Full error message

Full stack trace message is below;

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "apache_beam/runners/common.py", line 780, in apache_beam.runners.common.DoFnRunner.process
  File "apache_beam/runners/common.py", line 587, in apache_beam.runners.common.PerWindowInvoker.invoke_process

items.title: AttributeError: module 'tensorflow_data_validation' has no attribute 'validate_tfexamples_in_tfrecord'
items.body:
Hi, I'm following the tutorial here: https://www.tensorflow.org/tfx/data_validation/get_started
But when I try to run the code:
```Scala
   options = tfdv.StatsOptions(schema=schema)
   anomalous_example_stats = tfdv.validate_tfexamples_in_tfrecord(
       data_location=input, stats_options=options)
```
It shows error `AttributeError: module 'tensorflow_data_validation' has no attribute 'validate_tfexamples_in_tfrecord'`. My version is 0.21.5.

items.title: Facets don't render in M80 release of Chrome.
items.body:
tfdv.visualize_statistics() does not render after upgrading to Chrome M80.

Environment:

- MacOS Catalina
- Chrome - Version 80.0.3987.87 (Official Build) (64-bit)

Chrome 80 was released on Feb 4th.

items.title: ValidationError from generate_statistics_from_tfrecord pipeline
items.body:
We are running a `generate_statistics_from_tfrecord` pipeline that fails when run on Dataflow with a `ValidationError`

Pipeline code:
```
PROJECT = 'project'
JOB_NAME = 'job'
REGION = 'region'
N_WORKERS = None
GCS_TMP_LOCATION = 'gs://path/to/tmp'
GCS_DATA_LOCATION_BLOB = 'gs://path/to/*.tfrecord.gz'
# GCS_STATS_OUTPUT_PATH is the file path to which to output the data statistics
# result.
GCS_STATS_OUTPUT_PATH = 'gs://path/to/output'

# Create and set your PipelineOptions.
options = PipelineOptions()

pipeline_options_kwargs = {
  'runner': 'DataflowRunner',
  'project': PROJECT,
  'job_name': JOB_NAME,
  'region': REGION,
  'temp_location': GCS_TMP_LOCATION,
  'network': 'vpc',
  'subnetwork': 'https://www.googleapis.com/compute/v1/path/to/subnet',
  'use_public_ips': False,
  'save_main_session': True,
  'experiments': ['shuffle_mode=service'],
  'service_account_email': 'serviceaccount@project.iam.gserviceaccount.com',
  'autoscaling_algorithm': 'NONE' if N_WORKERS is not None else None,
  'num_workers': N_WORKERS,
  'setup_file': './dataflow_dependencies/setup.py'
}
pipeline_options = PipelineOptions(flags=[], **pipeline_options_kwargs)

stats = tfdv.generate_statistics_from_tfrecord(
  GCS_DATA_LOCATION_BLOB,
  output_path=GCS_STATS_OUTPUT_PATH,
  pipeline_options=pipeline_options
)
```

Error:
```
Progress reporting thread got error: Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/dataflow_worker/batchworker.py", line 234, in progress_reporting_thread
    state_sampler_info=state_sampler_info)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/dataflow_worker/batchworker.py", line 341, in report_status
    work_executor=self._work_executor)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/dataflow_worker/workerapiclient.py", line 420, in report_status
    work_item_status)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/dataflow_worker/workerapiclient.py", line 323, in _append_all_user_metric_updates
    metric_kind=dataflow.CounterMetadata.KindValueValuesEnum.SUM)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/dataflow_worker/workerapiclient.py", line 243, in _update_metrics
    status_object, metric_name, metric_kind, value=update, setter=setter)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/dataflow_worker/workerapiclient.py", line 143, in append_counter_update
    setter(value, metric_update)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/apache_beam/runners/dataflow/internal/apiclient.py", line 853, in translate_value
    metric_update_proto.integer = to_split_int(value)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/apache_beam/runners/dataflow/internal/apiclient.py", line 827, in to_split_int
    res.lowBits = n & 0xffffffff
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/apitools/base/protorpclite/messages.py", line 973, in __setattr__
    object.__setattr__(self, name, value)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/apitools/base/protorpclite/messages.py", line 1293, in __set__
    value = self.validate(value)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/apitools/base/protorpclite/messages.py", line 1400, in validate
    return self.__validate(value, self.validate_element)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/apitools/base/protorpclite/messages.py", line 1358, in __validate
    return validate_element(value)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/site-packages/apitools/base/protorpclite/messages.py", line 1340, in validate_element
    (self.type, name, value, type(value)))
apitools.base.protorpclite.messages.ValidationError: Expected type (<class 'int'>,) for field lowBits, found 1 (type <class 'numpy.int64'>)
```

Based on method names in the traceback, it seems like TFDV might be setting beam.metrics that take on `numpy.int64` values, which Dataflow then does not like.

Looking through the code, I see two main sites where beam.metrics are used, though there may be more:
https://github.com/tensorflow/data-validation/blob/40b29a57afbf90d5a9fb2f6f1cd1972f216b5f97/tensorflow_data_validation/statistics/generators/basic_stats_generator.py#L655
https://github.com/tensorflow/data-validation/blob/425beeab53fb6f615bb7387408bd208532c7fe01/tensorflow_data_validation/statistics/stats_impl.py#L570

Note that we have frozen and staged our dependencies onto Dataflow (no online installation), but this error is not immediately suggestive of a stale dependency or conflict.
We are using `Apache Beam Python 3.5 SDK 2.14.0`.

items.title: CrossFeature statistics aren't present in the result PB
items.body:
That simple code should populate `cross_features` field in the result pb object, but it doesn't:
```
import tensorflow_data_validation as tfdv
from tensorflow_data_validation.statistics.generators.cross_feature_stats_generator import CrossFeatureStatsGenerator
from tensorflow_data_validation.statistics import stats_options as options
g = CrossFeatureStatsGenerator(sample_rate=1.0,feature_crosses=[('fnlwgt','hours-per-week')])
stats_options = options.StatsOptions(generators=[g])
ordered_columns = [
          'age', 'workclass', 'fnlwgt', 'education', 'education-num',
          'marital-status', 'occupation', 'relationship', 'race', 'sex',
          'capital-gain', 'capital-loss', 'hours-per-week', 'native-country',
          'label'
      ]
train_stats = tfdv.generate_statistics_from_csv("datasets/adult/adult.data",
                                                delimiter=',', 
                                                column_names=ordered_columns,
                                               stats_options=stats_options)
```
If I inspect `train_stats.datasets[0].cross_features` it is an empty list.
It seems that the issue might be related to the merge function: 
https://github.com/tensorflow/data-validation/blob/master/tensorflow_data_validation/statistics/stats_impl.py#L332

items.title: Types missing in documentation / code for tfdv.CombinerStatsGenerator
items.body:
Methods in "abstract" classes should use type hinting as it can be hard to create custom implementations (e.g. combiner that derives `tfdv.CombinerStatsGenerator`) without prior reverse engineering of already implemented generators. 

Here is an example:

```
def extract_output(self, accumulator):  
    """Returns result of converting accumulator into the output value.
    Returns:
      A proto representing the result of this stats generator.
    """
```
What `proto` is expected here?  Can I create a custom one or do I have to use `statistics_pb2.DatasetFeatureStatistics` or maybe something else?

Here however:
```
  def merge_accumulators(self, accumulators):
    """Merges several accumulators to a single accumulator value.

    Args:
      accumulators: The accumulators to merge.
```
I have to guess that accumulators might be a list due to the plural form of the variable name, yet `accumulators:List[object]` would be helpful for my IDE.

Etc, you get the picture

items.title: Embedding Data Validation Visualization in iframe Fails due to DOMException
items.body:
Due to the usage of `facets_iframe.contentWindow.document.write` [here](https://github.com/tensorflow/data-validation/blob/a93f5328e6494f7cb36f7fe2859f1e0f70628950/tensorflow_data_validation/utils/display_util.py#L242), embedding a tfdv visualization within an iframe that is sandboxed is not possible. When attempting to embed a tfdv visualization within a sandboxed iframe, the following error is provided
```
Uncaught DOMException: Blocked a frame with origin "null" from accessing a cross-origin frame.
    at about:srcdoc:13129:37
```
The specific line it references is linked above. A work-around that I have been using is to replace:
```javascript
facets_iframe.contentWindow.document.write(facets_html);
```
with
```javascript
facets_iframe.srcdoc = facets_html;
```
By doing this the content of the iframe is still able to be manipulated without a DOMException being thrown. Do you have any recommendations for how to resolve this issue? My use case specifically requires that tfdv visualizations are embedded within an iframe.

I would be happy to submit a PR with a solution but I am not sure if the work-around that I am currently using is ideal.

items.title: TDFV==0.14.0 Wheel Fails Integrity Check
items.body:
It appears `TFDV==0.14.0` has a bad hash value and is failing the integrity check done by the resolver, `pex`:

`Exception message: Bad hash for file 'tensorflow_data_validation/pywrap/_pywrap_tensorflow_data_validation.so'`.

It has been reported (https://github.com/pypa/pip/issues/4705) that pip does not check the file hashes for integrity but other resolvers such as Pex do which leads to failures.  Thus, it appears there's some mutation after the wheel is built ? 

Minimal Repo:
```
pip install pex
pex tensorflow-data-validation==0.14.0 -o tfdv.pex
```

items.title: Documentation about anomalies and what constraints trigger them
items.body:
This issue is maybe related to https://github.com/tensorflow/data-validation/issues/62 where the answer is "We are working on a better documentation".

Generally, I would like to see a list of 
* possible anomalies
* what fields are compared to trigger them (between statistics and schema or statistics and statistics)
* What field in schema is responsible for the constraint (might be the same as above)

Specifically,
I want to protect myself against a integer feature suddenly having 100% of zero values. I am wondering if there is a field in the schema that I can set to validate this?

items.title: Unclear anomaly_info
items.body: I have inferred a schema and statistics on a TFRecords dataset. (unfortunately I cannot share the dataset). when I validate statistics against "its own" schema, I get anomalies for some of my features like: ``` u"'country_of_origin'": description: "Some examples have fewer values than expected." severity: ERROR short_description: "Missing values" reason { type: FEATURE_TYPE_LOW_NUMBER_VALUES short_description: "Missing values" description: "Some examples have fewer values than expected." } path { step: "country_of_origin" } ``` This is the relevant (inferred) part of my schema: ``` feature { name: "country_of_origin" value_count { min: 1 } type: BYTES presence { min_count: 1 } } ``` This is the representation of the relevant part of the statistics: I have several problems with this: 1. It looks like something weird happened with the quotes around the key of the anomaly_info. 1. The anomalies says: "Missing values", but my statistics says 0% missing values 1. Generally in TFDV, it's not clear which numbers are compared and raise an anomaly. For example here, is the error caused by the `value_count` or the `presence.min_count` part of my schema? In my statistics, which of this fields is used ?: - feature.string_stats.common_stats.min_num_values - feature.string_stats.common_stats.num_missing - feature.string_stats.common_stats.tot_num_values - feature.string_stats.common_stats.avg_num_values I suspect it's the first one but there is no other way for me to be sure than digging into the C++ code of this repository and this I don't know the codebase, I'm not 100% sure. 1. It also says: "Some examples have fewer values than expected." Ideally I would like to have more information to solve the problem or to account how severe the problem is: how many examples, which ones, how many values are missing, etc... 1. Depending on this results, maybe I would like to allow a portion of my dataset to have "fewer missing values" than what is required. But how could I define this? I would expect the content of the anomaly would give me more information about what exactly is the problem, what comparison is failing. Ideally it would also suggest one way to "silence" the anomaly if I which (could I change the severity for this error for example) or where to look in my dataset to find the root of the problem.

items.title: Any way to speed up tfdv.TFExampleDecoder?
items.body:
I think most users of this library will most likely be feeding in data from serialized `tf.train.Example`s stored in TFRecords. However, the performance of `tfdv.TFExampleDecoder` may become a bottleneck for some users. If you profile that code, you find that it spends minimal amounts of time deserializing the data and the vast majority of its time building the output dictionary and instantiating numpy arrays. The problem is exacerbated for workflows with hundreds or thousands of scalar features, where the overhead of creating small numpy arrays seems to dominate.

Do you have any tips for what can be done to optimize this part of the TFDV workflow? I've already tried swapping in `tft.coders.ExampleProtoCoder` in cases where the schema is known in advance, but it does not seem to provide very much of a performance gain (about 10%).

items.title: Make desired_batch_size argument public in GenerateStatistics API
items.body:
Hi, currently it's not possible to state `desired_batch_size` in the public API of [GenerateStatistics](https://github.com/tensorflow/data-validation/blob/6776903698e357541f35da0d1703efe4010ac627/tensorflow_data_validation/api/stats_api.py#L79).

Though the functionality is implemented in [`_BatchedCombineFnWrapper`](https://github.com/tensorflow/data-validation/blob/6776903698e357541f35da0d1703efe4010ac627/tensorflow_data_validation/statistics/stats_impl.py#L337)

The easiest way to use it is by adding it to `StatsOptions` and pass it [here](https://github.com/tensorflow/data-validation/blob/6776903698e357541f35da0d1703efe4010ac627/tensorflow_data_validation/statistics/stats_impl.py#L108) to `_BatchedCombineFnWrapper`.

The desired result would look like:
```python
class GenerateSlicedStatisticsImpl(beam.PTransform):

  def __init__(
      self,
      options = stats_options.StatsOptions(desired_batch_size=100)
      ):
    self._options = options
   ....
    for generator in stats_generators:
      ....       
          _BatchedCombineFnWrapper(generator,
           desired_batch_size=self._options.desired_batch_size)).with_hot_key_fanout(fanout))
```

Or is there a reason why it's hidden at the moment?

Thanks.

> In some cases the anomalies correspond to a natural evolution of the data, and the appropriate action is to change the schema (rather than fix the data). To accommodate this option, **our component generates for each anomaly a corresponding schema change that can bring the schema up-to-date**

items.title: AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute '_QuantilesCombinerSpec'
items.body:
While using `tfdv.generate_statistics_from_csv()` I get the error AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute '_QuantilesCombinerSpec', as noted [in](https://github.com/tensorflow/data-validation/issues/31).
This seems to be caused by Tensorflow transform changing the _QuantilesCombinerSpec in analyzers.py to QuantilesCombiner, which I think can be fixed by install tensorflow-transform==0.9.0.
I think the dependency on Tensorflow-transform in setup.py should be set <0.11 to avoid this error surfacing when installing via pip.

items.title: Slow performance when computing stats for moderately large data set
items.body:
Hi,

I like this project **a lot**, and thanks for releasing it! I see the potential to save a lot of time when I first receive new datasets. However, I have issues with performance.

OS: the notebook is running in a Docker container based on https://hub.docker.com/r/tensorflow/tensorflow/.

Hardware:
```
GPUs 16X NVIDIA® Tesla V100
GPU Memory 512GB total
CPU Dual Intel Xeon Platinum
8168, 2.7 GHz, 24-cores
System Memory 1.5TB
```
It takes me >8 hours (30900 s) to compute the statistics for a  ~100 dataset, with file sizes from 0.5 MB to 300 MB, with a median of 70 MB. It's true that the Docker container introduces some overhead, but given the specs of my hardware, I think it's too much. Any tips on how to speed up computations, w/o changing hardware (i.e., no cloud)? For example, if there was an option to compute statistics in a dataframe, rather than in a protocol buffer, one could use [Modin](https://github.com/modin-project/modin) to speedup pandas computations with minimal changes to code.

PS if I use a GPU container instead, with

`$ docker run --runtime=nvidia -it -p 8888:8888 tensorflow/tensorflow:latest-gpu
`
should I see a speedup?

items.title: GCP Dataflow file pattern *.tfrecord
items.body:
Not really an issue but something that people might encounter : 

Setting a glob pattern for data location in a Dataflow execution like `'dataset/train/*'` will crash the job. This is because even if you only generated `.tfrecord` files inside this "folder", there is something else here in the blob that's trying to be read by your decoder pipeline.

This might result in something like that :
`ValueError: Not a valid TFRecord. Mismatch of length mask: 934e554d5059010076007b27`

You have to be sure to select only tf records `'dataset/train/*.tfrecord'`

Hope it helps someone :)

items.title: Python 3 Support
items.body:
Currently, TFDV requires Python 2.7 due to dependency on Apache Beam, which is not compatible with Python 3 yet. 

But Python 3 support should be available very soon, as [Apache Beam is almost Python 3 ready](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-1251).
